comments.commentBody: Ron Paul's argument isn't about segregation (he's against).  It is about federalism and the limits to governmental power.  Some people made that argument because they wanted to maintain segregation, but it is also possible to make it as a question of the meaning of the Contitution.  It is still wrong, as decided by the courts, but the motive for making it is more honorable.  Not all expansions of governmental power are either benign or Constitutional, even if this one was.

The U.S. has never come to terms with Vietnam.  It is fairly amazing that any politician needs to doctor a resume to reflect war duty.  Ronald Reagan sanitized that war with the rhetoric of a "noble cause," in part to get on with a far-right ideological agenda. What was noble about millions dead, free-fire zones, the use of napalm against civilians, and grotesque violations of the rules of war vis-a-vis civilians?  Even the Gulf of Tonkin incident was a charade used by the Johnson administration to justify an immoral war.  The government of the U.S. needed to have let the people of Vietnam settle a civil war among themselves.  Communism did not triumph, however, a wider more lethal and genocidal war in Cambodia ensued.

What "torturous guilt"? All I felt was immense relief when I drew a high enough draft number in 1972. When Nixon ended the draft the following winter (or maybe the winter after), it was announced over the Hope College dining hall p.a. system, to wild applause. What exactly did we accomplish in  Vietnam? I feel no more guilt at not having fought or died there than I do not being one of the thousands of Americans who perish in automobile accidents every year. The other point, often overlooked, is that America had far too many young men of fighting age during the Vietnam War for all to have served in the Army. Selective  Service, for all its faults, was a system for dealing with that oversupply of cannon fodder. College deferments came about because  General Lewis Hershey, director of Selective Service, did not want the U.S. to lose large numbers of its smartest and best-educated young men, as  Britain did in World War I.
